Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis, Synthetic Mechanism, and Single Particle Microscopy of Colloidal Semiconductor Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Todd Krauss of the University of Rochester is studying tiny inorganic particles called colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs). These NCs have the potential to impact numerous areas of active research and technology due to their size-dependent properties. However, the lack of a rational synthetic mechanism has impeded advances in NC design and applications. This project investigates new fundamental strategies for low-temperature NC syntheses that are potentially scalable to industrial volumes, and thus are compatible with current chemical manufacturing procedures. Large-scale synthesis of semiconductor NCs, especially those with reduced toxicity, may enable the development of new applications in biology and medicine, optics and photonics. This project provides for the education and training of two graduate students and one undergraduate student. The two graduate students also organize and direct outreach efforts through interfacing with the Rochester Museum and Science Center.

A long-standing and significant challenge in the field of colloidal semiconductor NCs is to understand at a fundamental level how NCs are synthesized, and to use this knowledge to make improved NCs in a rational manner. The overall goal in this project is to develop a more detailed understanding of NC synthesis mechanisms in route to synthesizing NCs with improved chemical or photophysical properties. Several experiments are conducted utilizing optical, mass and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopies to obtain more complete understanding of the chemical reaction mechanism for the NCs of interest. Also, the important relationship between charge, photoluminescence and impurity atom concentration for doped semiconductor NCs are being determined. These studies will aid in the understanding of unexplained photophysical phenomena in a wide class of nanostructured materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tiny, inorganic particles called colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals (NCs) have the potential to impact numerous areas of active research and technology due to their size-dependent properties. However, a long-standing and significant challenge in the field of colloidal semiconductor NCs is to understand at a fundamental level how NCs are synthesized, and to use this knowledge to make improved NCs in a rational manner. During the course of this project we have discovered the surprisingly complicated mechanism by which cadmium selenide (CdSe) NCs are synthesized from starting, molecular precursors. We also investigated the mechanism by which individual impurity atoms of silver (Ag) are added to CdSe NCs, and the photophysical properties of the resulting NCs, both of which are not well understood. In particular, we showed that surface bound Ag atoms explain the unusual absorption and photoluminescence spectra of the doped NCs, solving a longstanding puzzle. We also demonstrated that the doping process is highly heterogeneous, meaning that the amount of silver atoms per nanocrystal is highly variable. Somewhat unexpectedly, some NCs were found to be completely untouched while others were almost saturated with silver atoms. These advances will allow for improvements to the doping process and the synthesis of doped NCs with controllable optical properties.

 

Finally, we also constructed an optical microscope with the capability to acquire photoluminescence images beyond what is ordinarily possible with conventional optics such as lenses and mirrors, called a super-resolution microscope. Important for such a microscope is to understand what materials or molecules that emit light can produce the highest resolution images. To that end we have shown in this project that colloidal NCs produce higher quality images compared to more traditional photoluminescent emitters such as organic dye molecules. Further, we discovered the key, fundamental characteristics of NCs that are responsible for their superior performance. 

 

In terms of a broader impact, the entire semiconductor microfabrication industry is based on controlled impurity doping of silicon. A better understanding of doping for NCs could someday lead to groundbreaking devices such as a minute transistor that could be literally assembled from solution into functional, integrated circuits. Likewise, our more complete understanding of the underlying growth mechanism of semiconductor NCs will allow for follow on improvements in their synthetic methodology, and development of novel types of nanoparticle compositions and structures. Broadly, this research program will have impact in biomedical imaging, novel electronics and photonics, and other areas of national, medical, economic and security interest.

 

Students received training in several areas besides developing their technical skills in the laboratory. All graduate students presented the results of their research at group meetings and some at national meetings and conferences. In addition, support from this project helped to train several students who are under-represented in the physical sciences. Four undergraduate students and one high school student involved in the project were mentored by participating graduate students, acquiring valuable technical skills in materials and physical chemistry, optics and physics, and materials science. Also, supported graduate students led outreach efforts to the general public through weekend activities at the Rochester Museum and Science Center, and at local Rochester city schools.
